full_translation:
*The Expanded and Abridged Commentaries on the True Meaning of the Dao and Its Virtue*
**Scripture Title:** *Expanded and Abridged Commentaries on the True Meaning of the Dao and Its Virtue*
Originally titled *Imperial Commentary on the Dao De Jing by Emperor Xuanzong of Tang*.
Four fascicles, included in the *Daoist Canon of the Zhengtong Era* under the *Jade Instructions* category of the *Dongshen* section.

According to the *External Transmission* at the beginning of this text and its main content, this work is an abridged and revised version of Du Guangting’s *Expanded Commentaries on the True Meaning of the Dao and Its Virtue* from the Tang dynasty. The reviser’s identity is unknown; the current title is provisionally assigned based on the content. The remaining fascicle titles follow the original *Daoist Canon* without alteration.

---

**External Transmission on the Commentary to the Dao De Jing**

The Most High (Tai Shang) arises from no cause, emerging from the profound (xuan), unfathomable and inscrutable. Though named from existence, it manifests in accordance with conditions, impossible to fully recount. In later ages, it transformed during the Yin dynasty, taking form in the womb of the eighteenth Yin king, Yang Jia, in the seventeenth year of the gengshen cycle. It gestated within the Mysterious and Wondrous Jade Maiden for eighty-one years, until the ninth year of King Wu Ding of the Yin, in the gengchen cycle, when it descended and was born in Bozhou’s Weizhen County—now the site of the Supreme Clarity Palace, the very place of its birth.

On the fifteenth day of the second month, at the hour of mao, the Sage Mother gave birth by splitting open her left armpit. Other auspicious omens are fully recorded in the histories of the Dao.

The *Dao De Jing* has been annotated by many scholars across the ages. Over sixty extant commentaries are listed below:

- *Sectional Exegesis* (Upper and Lower Fascicles): Commentary by Lord Lao and Yin Xi.
- *Xiang’er* (Two Fascicles): Annotations by Zhang Daoling, the Three Heavens’ Dharma Master.
- *Inner Exegesis* (Upper and Lower Fascicles): Yin Xi’s commentary on the principles of inner cultivation.
- *Master Heshang’s Chapter and Verse*: Descended and dwelled by the riverbanks of Shanzhou during the reign of Emperor Wen of Han; a temple still stands there today.
- *Zhigui* (Fourteen Fascicles) by Yan Junping: A man of Shu during the reign of Emperor Cheng of Han, named Yan Zun.
- *Annotations* by Wang Bi of Shanyang: Courtesy name Fusi, a Gentleman of the Imperial Secretariat during the Wei.
- *Nanyang He Yan*: Courtesy name Shuping, a son-in-law commandant of the Wei.
- *Guo Xiang of Henan*: Courtesy name Zixuan, a disciple of Xiang Xiu, of the Wei-Jin period.
- *Zhong Hui of Yingchuan*: Courtesy name Shiji, of the reign of Emperor Ming of Wei.
- *Recluse Sun Deng*: Courtesy name Gonghe, active during the reigns of Emperors Wen and Ming of Wei.
- *Shepherd of Jin, Yang Hu of Taishan*: Courtesy name Shuzi, whose commentary comprises four fascicles.
- *Śramaṇa Kumārajīva*: Originally from the Western Hu, entered China through the Jade Gate Pass during the reign of Fu Jian, annotating two fascicles.
- *Śramaṇa Fotucheng*: A Western Hu monk of the Zhao dynasty, annotating two fascicles (Upper and Lower).
- *Śramaṇa Sengzhao*: Of the Jin dynasty, annotating four fascicles.
- *Recluse Tao Hongjing of Liang*: Of the reign of Emperor Wu, styled Master Zhenbai, annotating four fascicles.
- *Lu Yu of Fanyang*: Erudite of the National University during the Later Wei, nicknamed the White-Headed Elder, annotating two fascicles.
- *Liu Renhui, a Rustic Gentleman*: Of Liang County in Yizhou during the Later Wei, annotating two fascicles.
- *Recluse Gu Huan of Wu Commandery*: Courtesy name Jingyi, a scholar of the Southern Qi, annotating four fascicles.
- *Immortal of Pine Spirit*: Dwelled in Mount Qingxi; name and era unknown.
- *Pei Chuen of Hedong, Jin*: Annotated two fascicles.
- *Du Bi of Jingzhao, Qin*: Annotated two fascicles.
- *Zhang Ping of Henan, Song*: Courtesy name Changzong, a Gentleman of the Imperial Sacrifices during the reign of Emperor Ming, annotating four fascicles.
- *Emperor Wu of Liang*: Xiao Yan, annotating four fascicles, interpreting the text through the lens of cause and effect.
- *Emperor Jianwen of Liang*: Xiao Gang, composing *Narrative Exegesis* in ten fascicles.
- *Zhang Si of Qingjiang*: Annotated four fascicles; era unknown.
- *Daoist Zang Xuanjing of Liang*: Courtesy name Daozong, composing a commentary in four fascicles.
- *Daoist Meng Anpai of Liang*: Styled Great Meng, composing *Exegesis of the Scripture* in two fascicles.
- *Daoist Meng Zhizhou of Liang*: Styled Little Meng, annotating two fascicles.
- *Daoist Dou Lüe of Liang*: Annotated four fascicles, following the same principles as Emperor Wu and Kumārajīva.
- *Daoist Liu Jinxī of Sui*: Composed a commentary in six fascicles.
- *Daoist Zhu Rou of Chen*: Composed *Profound Insight* in six fascicles.
- *Daoist Li Bo of Sui*: Annotated two fascicles (Upper and Lower).
- *Grand Scribe of Tang, Fu Yi*: Annotated two fascicles, also composing *Phonetic and Semantic Glosses*.
- *Daoist Wei Zheng of Mount Song*: Composed *Essential Meaning*, a chancellor under Emperor Taizong.
- *Dharma Master Song Wenming*: Composed *Fountain of Meaning* in five fascicles.
- *Immortal Hu Chao*: Composed *Exegetical Commentary* in ten fascicles, having attained the Dao on the Western Mountains.
- *Daoist An Qiu*: Composed *Pointers to the Return* in five fascicles.
- *Daoist Yin Wencao*: Composed *Simplified Essential Meaning* in five fascicles.
- *Dharma Master Wei Lu*: Courtesy name Chuxuan, annotating and interpreting four fascicles.
- *Daoist Wang Xuanbian*: Composed *Master Heshang’s Exegesis* in ten fascicles.
- *Remonstrance Gentleman and Abbot of Suming Abbey, Yin Yin*: Composed *New Exegesis* in fifteen fascicles.
- *Daoist Xu Miao*: Annotated four fascicles.
- *Academician and Daoist He Siyuan*: Composed *Pointers to the Essentials* in two fascicles and *Profound Instructions* in eight fascicles.
- *Daoist Xue Jichang of Mount Heng*: Composed *Golden Rope* in ten fascicles and *Numerical Principles* in one fascicle.
- *Master Hongyuan, Wang Di*: Annotated two fascicles, *Mystic Pearl* in three fascicles, and *Essential Instructions* in two fascicles.
- *Dharma Master Zhao Jian*: Composed *Lecture Commentary* in six fascicles.
- *Gentleman for Consultation of the Crown Prince, Yang Shangshan*: Of the reign of Emperor Gaozong, composed *Collected Annotations and True Sayings* in twenty fascicles.
- *Daoist Che Bi*: Composed a commentary in seven fascicles.
- *Renzi, Li Rong*: Annotated two fascicles (Upper and Lower).
- *Daoist Li Yuanxing of Chengdu*: Composed *Exegesis* in four fascicles.
- *Vice Prefect of Taiyuan, Wang Guangting*: Composed *Contracting the Origin* in two fascicles.
- *Daoist Zhang Huichao*: Composed *Aspiration to the Mysterious Commentary* in four fascicles.
- *Dharma Master Gong*: Composed *Collected Explanations* in four fascicles.
- *Discussion Gentleman and Daoist Ren Daxuan of Tongyi Commandery*: Annotated two fascicles.
- *Daoist Shen Fu, Master of Emptiness and Palace Supervisor*: Composed a commentary in five fascicles.
- *Daoist Zhang Junxiang of Mount Min*: Composed *Collected Explanations* in four fascicles.
- *Daoist Cheng Xuanying*: Composed *Lecture Commentary* in six fascicles.
- *Governor of Hanzhou, Wang Zhen*: Composed *On Warfare and Narrative Exegesis* in two fascicles (Upper and Lower).

Daoist Fu Shaoming composed *Daoist Lectures and Strategies* in two fascicles.

The August Emperor Xuanzong annotated the *Daode jing* in two fascicles (Upper and Lower) and composed a *Lecture Commentary* in six fascicles—this is the now widely disseminated exegesis. The principles he expounded differ from those of other schools: some delve deeply into the profound mystery of the Twofold Mystery, unconfined by emptiness or being; some trace karmic causes and effects, adhering rigidly to the three lifetimes; some draw parallels with Confucian teachings, while others incline toward the quiescence of emptiness. Yet all have plumbed the depths of the dragon’s chamber, vying to gather its pearls and jades; all have traversed Mount Zhong, striving to glimpse its ritual scepters. Each holds a Liancheng gem in hand, their bosoms filled with radiant treasures. In their propagation, they illuminate silk scrolls with resplendent light; in their exposition, they adorn bamboo slips with vibrant patterns.

Our August Emperor of Kaiyuan, the Illustrious and Reverent Filial Sovereign, descended in divine transformation, succeeding the celestial mandate with timely virtue. He quelled internal strife, ascended the throne through the power of Qian, and ruled with effortless governance, presiding over forty-five years. From the Fen River to Xiangcheng, his chariot tracks left no trace of toil; from the great halls of Juci, he roamed in luminous freedom. He expanded the Eight Seas into a court of benevolence and longevity, and transformed the myriad dwellings into a realm of Huaxu. His Way and virtue transcendent—how luminous! How sublime!

Revering the sacred scriptures, they form the ancestral teachings of our dynasty—so profound their symbolic lineage that no analogy may suffice, so lofty their elegance that no rhetoric can fully express. They span the ages, standing alone in the cosmos. Though many schools have wielded their brushes, none have exhausted the gates of myriad wonders; though countless scholars have refined their studies, none have attained the realm of profound mystery.

In moments of leisure amid the weight of governance, the Emperor’s thoughts turned to their source. He personally annotated the eighty-one chapters and composed a six-volume commentary. Within, it encompasses the root of self-cultivation without omission; without, it sets forth the methods of statecraft, great and small alike. His imperial compositions spread far and wide, outshining the splendor of five-colored clouds; the radiance of heaven descended, enhancing the brilliance of the sun and moon. Truly, it may rival the *Ten Wings* of Ji Zhong, illuminating the *Two Southern* odes. As if receiving instruction directly from the Mysterious Origin, it bears the authentic transmission of the Most High. It crowns the nine schools of thought and stands preeminent, destined to endure through ten thousand ages without erasure. Thus, the songs of *Great Wind* and *Crimson Wild Geese* can scarcely follow in its footsteps; the works of *Classic Discourse* and *Golden Tower* cannot be mentioned in the same breath.

Yet within these commentaries and annotations, where scriptures are cited to align with their meanings, the *Book of Zhou* and the *Annals of Lu* mutually elucidate one another, while the *Four Beginnings* and the writings of Qiyuan occasionally clarify categories. Later scholars, upon perusing these volumes, often remain obscured to their foundational sources. Therefore, I have gathered and excerpted from various texts, delving into scrolls and chapters. Now, among the Emperor’s annotations and commentaries, I record these supplementary matters below.

In the eleventh year of Kaiyuan, the Emperor personally composed the preface to the annotations, stating:

A *zhao* is an imperial edict, a written command. For the Son of Heaven, these are termed *zhao*, *gao*, *chi*, or *zhi*; for the Empress, Crown Prince, and various princes, they are called *jiao* or *ling*—all words by which superiors command their inferiors.

*"Zhao"* enlightens future generations. *"Qi"* means to open; *"di"* means to advance. *"Po"* means greatly.

The commentary’s preface states: Sima Qian called him a "reclusive gentleman." Sima Qian was the Grand Historian, styled Zichang, a native of Wen in Henei, grandson of Sima Xi, Chancellor to the King of Zhongshan, and son of Sima Tan, the Grand Astrologer, a descendant of Zhuanxu. Born at Longmen, at ten he recited the *Ancient Script* version of the *Book of Documents*; at twenty, he traveled to Jianghuai, Jiuyi, and the gates of Yu’s cave. He served the Han as Gentleman-in-Attendance and was dispatched to the western regions of Shu. A year after his father’s death, he became Grand Astrologer and composed the *Records of the Grand Historian*.

The *Dao and Virtue* is divided into upper and lower sections. In the twenty-first year of Kaiyuan, this division was promulgated. The distinctions are as follows: the upper volume, comprising four nines—thirty-six chapters—corresponds to spring, summer, autumn, and winter. The lower volume, comprising five nines—forty-five chapters—corresponds to metal, wood, water, fire, and earth. Thus, the upper volume, from chapter one to nine, takes formlessness and namelessness as its essence, illuminating the Way of spring. From chapter ten to eighteen, it takes unknowing and the indistinct as its essence, illuminating the Way of summer. From chapter nineteen to twenty-seven, it takes having sentiment and trust as its essence, illuminating the Way of autumn. From chapter twenty-eight to thirty-six, it takes solemnity and purity as its essence, illuminating the Way of winter. In the lower volume, chapters one through nine expound the virtue of benevolence; chapters ten through eighteen, the virtue of propriety; chapters nineteen through twenty-seven, the virtue of righteousness; chapters twenty-eight through thirty-six, the virtue of wisdom; and chapters thirty-seven through forty-five, the virtue of trust.

chunks.original_text: 道德真经广圣义节略 经名：道德真经广圣义节略。 原题《唐玄宗御制道德真经疏》。 四卷，收入《正统道藏》洞神部玉诀类。 按此书卷首《外传》及正文内容，系据唐人杜光庭《道德真经广圣义》，加以节略改编而成。 改编者不知为谁，今暂据内容报定经名。 其徐卷题均依原《道藏》不变。 道德真经疏外传 太上者起乎无因，自玄而出，窅兮莫测，从有而名，随方出显，不可具陈。 后末化於殷朝，寄胎於商第十八王阳甲，十七年庚申之岁，托孕於玄妙玉女八十一年，至商二十二王武丁九年庚辰之岁，降生於亳州卫真县，今太清宫，是降生之所也。 二月十五日卯时，圣母剖左腋而生，其他祥异，备具道史。 《道德经》古今笺注者多矣，见行注者六十余家，开列于后： 节解上下　老君与尹喜解。 想尔二卷　三天法师张道陵所注。 内解上下　尹喜以内修之旨解注。 河上翁章句　汉文帝时降居陕州河滨，今有庙见存。 严君平指归十四卷　汉成帝时蜀人，名遵。 山阳王弼注　字辅嗣，魏时尚书郎。 南阳何晏　字叔平，魏驸马都尉。 河南郭象　字子玄，向秀弟子，魏晋时人。 颖川锺会　字士季，魏明帝时人。 隐士孙登　字公和，魏文、明二帝时人。 晋仆射太山羊祜　字叔子，注为四卷。 沙门罗什　本西胡人，苻坚时自玉门关入中国，注二卷。 沙门佛图澄　赵时西国胡僧也，注上下二卷。 沙门僧肇　晋时人，注四卷。 梁隐居陶弘景　武帝时人，号贞白先生，注四卷。 范阳庐裕　后魏国子博士，名白头翁，注二卷。 草莱臣刘仁会　后魏伊州梁县人，注二卷。 昊郡征士顾欢　字景怡，南齐博士，注四卷。 松灵仙人　隐青溪山，无名氏年代。 晋人河东裴楚恩　注二卷。 秦人京兆杜弼　注二卷。 宋人河南张凭　字长宗，明帝太常博士，注四卷。 梁武帝　萧衍，注四卷，证以因果为义。 梁简文帝　萧纲，作述义十卷。 清江张嗣　注四卷，无年代。 梁道士臧玄静　字道宗，作疏四卷。 梁道士孟安排　号大孟，作经义二卷。 梁道士孟智周　号小孟，注二卷。 梁道士窦略　注四卷，与武帝、罗什所宗无异。 隋道士刘进喜　作疏六卷。 陈道士诸糅　作玄览六卷。 隋道士李播　注上下二卷。 唐太史令傅弈　注二卷，并作音义。 唐嵩山道士魏征　作要义，太宗丞相。 法师宋文明　作义泉五卷。 仙人胡超　作义疏十卷，西山得道。 道士安丘　作指归五卷。 道士尹文操　作简要义五卷。 法师韦录　字处玄，注兼义四卷。 道士王玄辩　作河公释义十卷。 谏议大夫肃明观主尹愔　作新义＋五卷。 道士徐邈　注四卷。 直翰林道士何思远　作指趣二卷，玄示八卷。 衡岳道士薛季昌　作金绳十卷，事数一卷。 洪源先生王鞮　注二卷，玄珠三卷，旨诀二卷。 法师赵坚　作讲疏六卷。 太子司议郎杨上善　高宗时人，作集注真言二十卷。 道士车弼　疏七卷。 任真子李荣　注上下二卷。 成都道士黎元兴　作义四卷。 太原少尹王光庭　作契原注二卷。 道士张慧超　作志玄疏四卷。 龚法师　作集解四卷。 通议郡道士任大玄　注二卷。 道士冲虚先生殿中监申甫　作疏五卷。 岷山道士张君相　集解四卷。 道士成玄英　作讲疏六卷。 汉州刺史王真　作论兵述义上下二卷。

chunks.original_text: 道士符少明　作道讲策二卷。 玄宗皇帝　所注道德经上下二卷，讲疏六卷，即今所广疏矣。 所释之理，诸家不同，或深了重玄，不滞空有。 或推因果，偏执三生。 或引合儒宗，或趣归空寂。 莫不并探骊室，竞掇珠玑。 俱涉锺山，争窥珪瓒。 连城在握，照乘盈怀。 敷弘则光灿缣缃，演畅则彩文编简。 我开元至道昭肃孝皇帝，降神龙变，接统象先，戡内难以，乘乾启中，具而御极，无为在宥，四十五年，汾水襄城，靡劳辙迹，具茨大院，自得明游。 廓八溟为仁寿之庭，普万寓为华胥之国。 至道至德，超哉明哉。

Daoist Fu Shaoming composed *Daoist Lectures and Strategies* in two fascicles.

The August Emperor Xuanzong annotated the *Daode jing* in two fascicles (Upper and Lower) and composed a *Lecture Commentary* in six fascicles—this is the now widely disseminated exegesis. The principles he expounded differ from those of other schools: some delve deeply into the profound mystery of the Twofold Mystery, unconfined by emptiness or being; some trace karmic causes and effects, adhering rigidly to the three lifetimes; some draw parallels with Confucian teachings, while others incline toward the quiescence of emptiness. Yet all have plumbed the depths of the dragon’s chamber, vying to gather its pearls and jades; all have traversed Mount Zhong, striving to glimpse its ritual scepters. Each holds a Liancheng gem in hand, their bosoms filled with radiant treasures. In their propagation, they illuminate silk scrolls with resplendent light; in their exposition, they adorn bamboo slips with vibrant patterns.

Our August Emperor of Kaiyuan, the Illustrious and Reverent Filial Sovereign, descended in divine transformation, succeeding the celestial mandate with timely virtue. He quelled internal strife, ascended the throne through the power of Qian, and ruled with effortless governance, presiding over forty-five years. From the Fen River to Xiangcheng, his chariot tracks left no trace of toil; from the great halls of Juci, he roamed in luminous freedom. He expanded the Eight Seas into a court of benevolence and longevity, and transformed the myriad dwellings into a realm of Huaxu. His Way and virtue transcendent—how luminous! How sublime!

chunks.original_text: 钦若尊经，本朝家教，象系不可以拟议，风雅不足以指陈。 横亘古今，独立宇宙。 虽诸家染翰，未穷众妙之门； 多士研精，莫造重玄之境。 凝旒多暇，属想有归，躬注八十一章，制疏六卷。 内则修身之本，囊括无遗。 外即理国之方，洪纤毕举。 宸藻遐布，夺五云之华； 天光焕临，增二曜之色。 固可以季仲《十翼》，晖映二《南》。 禀若亲於玄元，信躬传於太上。 冠九流而首出，垂万古而不刊。 则《大风》、《朱雁》之歌，诚难接武； 《典论》、《金楼》之作，讵可同年。 但以疏注之中，引经合义，周书鲁史，互有发明，四始漆园，或申属类。 后学披卷，多瞢本源。 辄采摭众书，研寻篇轴。 今於御注疏内余事，略录于后。 开元十一年躬为注解序云：诏曰诏者，敕命之书也。 在天子为诏、为诰、为敕、为制，在皇后太子诸王为教、为令，皆君上命下之词也。 诏启迪来裔，启，开也。 迪，进也。 颇者，甚也。 疏序曰：马迁谓之隐君子。 马迁者，司马迁也。 字子长，河内温人，中山王相司马喜之孙，太史令谈之子，颛顼之裔。 生于龙门。 年十岁诵古文尚书，年二十岁游江淮、九疑、禹穴之门，仕汉为郎中，使西蜀。 父卒岁余为太史令，而作《史记》也。 《道德》分上下者，开元二十一年颁下，其所分别，上卷四九三十六章，法春夏秋冬，下卷五九四十五章，法金木水火土，则上卷从一至九章，以无形无名为宗，明春道。 从十至十八章，以无知恍惚为宗，明夏道。 从十九至二十七章，以有情有信为宗，明秋道。 从二十八至三十六章，以凝重清净为宗，明冬道。 其下卷自一尽九，明仁德。 次十尽十八，明礼德。 从十九尽二十七，明义德。 从二十八至三十六，明智德。 从三十七至尽四十五，明信德也。
chunks.translated_text:
Revering the sacred scriptures, they form the ancestral teachings of our dynasty—so profound their symbolic lineage that no analogy may suffice, so lofty their elegance that no rhetoric can fully express. They span the ages, standing alone in the cosmos. Though many schools have wielded their brushes, none have exhausted the gates of myriad wonders; though countless scholars have refined their studies, none have attained the realm of profound mystery.

In moments of leisure amid the weight of governance, the Emperor’s thoughts turned to their source. He personally annotated the eighty-one chapters and composed a six-volume commentary. Within, it encompasses the root of self-cultivation without omission; without, it sets forth the methods of statecraft, great and small alike. His imperial compositions spread far and wide, outshining the splendor of five-colored clouds; the radiance of heaven descended, enhancing the brilliance of the sun and moon. Truly, it may rival the *Ten Wings* of Ji Zhong, illuminating the *Two Southern* odes. As if receiving instruction directly from the Mysterious Origin, it bears the authentic transmission of the Most High. It crowns the nine schools of thought and stands preeminent, destined to endure through ten thousand ages without erasure. Thus, the songs of *Great Wind* and *Crimson Wild Geese* can scarcely follow in its footsteps; the works of *Classic Discourse* and *Golden Tower* cannot be mentioned in the same breath.

Yet within these commentaries and annotations, where scriptures are cited to align with their meanings, the *Book of Zhou* and the *Annals of Lu* mutually elucidate one another, while the *Four Beginnings* and the writings of Qiyuan occasionally clarify categories. Later scholars, upon perusing these volumes, often remain obscured to their foundational sources. Therefore, I have gathered and excerpted from various texts, delving into scrolls and chapters. Now, among the Emperor’s annotations and commentaries, I record these supplementary matters below.

In the eleventh year of Kaiyuan, the Emperor personally composed the preface to the annotations, stating:

A *zhao* is an imperial edict, a written command. For the Son of Heaven, these are termed *zhao*, *gao*, *chi*, or *zhi*; for the Empress, Crown Prince, and various princes, they are called *jiao* or *ling*—all words by which superiors command their inferiors.

*"Zhao"* enlightens future generations. *"Qi"* means to open; *"di"* means to advance. *"Po"* means greatly.

The commentary’s preface states: Sima Qian called him a "reclusive gentleman." Sima Qian was the Grand Historian, styled Zichang, a native of Wen in Henei, grandson of Sima Xi, Chancellor to the King of Zhongshan, and son of Sima Tan, the Grand Astrologer, a descendant of Zhuanxu. Born at Longmen, at ten he recited the *Ancient Script* version of the *Book of Documents*; at twenty, he traveled to Jianghuai, Jiuyi, and the gates of Yu’s cave. He served the Han as Gentleman-in-Attendance and was dispatched to the western regions of Shu. A year after his father’s death, he became Grand Astrologer and composed the *Records of the Grand Historian*.

The *Dao and Virtue* is divided into upper and lower sections. In the twenty-first year of Kaiyuan, this division was promulgated. The distinctions are as follows: the upper volume, comprising four nines—thirty-six chapters—corresponds to spring, summer, autumn, and winter. The lower volume, comprising five nines—forty-five chapters—corresponds to metal, wood, water, fire, and earth. Thus, the upper volume, from chapter one to nine, takes formlessness and namelessness as its essence, illuminating the Way of spring. From chapter ten to eighteen, it takes unknowing and the indistinct as its essence, illuminating the Way of summer. From chapter nineteen to twenty-seven, it takes having sentiment and trust as its essence, illuminating the Way of autumn. From chapter twenty-eight to thirty-six, it takes solemnity and purity as its essence, illuminating the Way of winter. In the lower volume, chapters one through nine expound the virtue of benevolence; chapters ten through eighteen, the virtue of propriety; chapters nineteen through twenty-seven, the virtue of righteousness; chapters twenty-eight through thirty-six, the virtue of wisdom; and chapters thirty-seven through forty-five, the virtue of trust.
